questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding Turner syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Turner syndrome with webbed neck is 3 times more likely to develop CVS defects than non webbed neck

options.label: B
options.text: Coarctation of aorta is more likely in non webbed neck

options.label: C
options.text: Male turner (Noonan syndrome) is much more likely to have CVS defects

options.label: D
options.text: Turner syndrome with webbed fingers and toes is likely to be associated with visceral anomalies

questions.correct_answer: A. Turner syndrome with webbed neck is 3 times more likely to develop CVS defects than non webbed neck
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Turner syndrome with webbed neck is 3 times more likely to develop CVS defects than non webbed neck > C. [A. Turner syndrome with webbed neck is 3 times more likely to develop CVS defects than non webbed neck; C. Male turner (Noonan syndrome) is much more likely to have CVS defects] Turner syndrome is 45, XO and thus occurs only in females while Noonan syndrome occurs due to somatic gene mutations in genes involved in RAS– MAPK pathway, with PTPN missense mutations being seen in >50% patients and thus can be seen in both males and females. Phenotypically, both syndromes appear similar and have overlapping features, including webbed neck and increased risk of congenital heart disease. Most common congenital heart disease in turner syndrome is bicuspid aortic valve, followed by coarctation of aorta. Most common congenital heart disease in Noonan syndrome is pulmonic stenosis. Regarding webbed neck due to any cause, it is associated with both flow-related as well as non-flow related cardiac defects. The webbed neck produces increased lymphatic pressure due to jugular lymphatic sac obstruction in a fetus, this compresses the ascending aorta. This further causes redirection of intracardiac blood flow, leading to coarctation of aorta. The largest multicentric study says that prevalence of CoA in turner syndrome is about 30% in webbed neck and 9–10% in normal neck. Thereby implying 3-fold increased risk of CoA in webbed neck Turner syndrome, versus non-webbed neck. Now confusion can arise from option C, since some older studies have reported that Noonan syndrome has association of cardiac disease in 70% cases, while Turner syndrome has association in 40% cases. However, this association is for detectable cardiac lesions like CoA and does not consider bicuspid aortic valve which are often asymptomatic. Also, Noonan syndrome is not a single lesion but a large spectrum of similar morphology due to specific pathway defects. Incidence of such high cardiac disease association has not been found to be consistently associated with all forms.

Highyeild:

Turner syndrome occurs in approximately 1 in 2500 newborn phenotypic females. Karyotypic Abnormalities: The most common karyotype observed in Turner syndrome is 45X, indicating a missing X chromosome. However, mosaic forms like 45X/46XX and 45X/46XY can also be seen. Clinical Features: Short Stature: Girls with Turner syndrome typically have a short stature. Phenotypic Characteristics: At birth, Turner syndrome may be identified by the presence of lymphedema, cystic hygroma, and left-sided obstructive cardiac lesions. Childhood Features: Other features in childhood may include cubitus valgus (wide carrying angle), shield chest with widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and a short fourth metacarpal bone. Cardiac Associations: Common cardiac associations include coarctation of the aorta, mitral valve prolapse, and aortic stenosis. Renal Malformations: Renal malformations like horseshoe kidney, duplication of renal pelvis, and agenesis may be present. Endocrine Associations: Turner syndrome can be associated with hypothyroidism and diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has peculiar facial features, enlarged head, hepatosplenomegaly, protuberant abdomen, breathing difficulty with obstructive sleep apnea, and cardiac valve thickening. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hunter’s disease Hurler syndrome, also called as MPS-IH, is virtually similar to Hunter disease, except few points.

Highyeild:

Hurler syndrome Hunter syndrome • It is known as MPS-IH • It is known as MPS-II • It is autosomal recessive • It is X-linked recessive disorder caused by deficiency of Iduronate 2-sulfatase (IDS) • Seen in both sexes • Exclusively seen in boys • Most commonly seen between 6 months and 2 years • It has severe intellectual disability and is severe with fatality by 10 years age • It is mild, presents in first decade between 2 and 4 years with coarse features, short stature • Corneal clouding : Present • Corneal clouding : Absent

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A: Hurler's disease , also known as Hurler syndrome or Mucopolysaccharidosis I (MPS I), is another genetic disorder that results from the deficiency of a different enzyme called alpha-L-iduronidase. It also causes the accumulation of GAGs in the body. OPTION B: Fragile X syndrome is a genetic condition caused by the expansion of a specific region in the X chromosome. It leads to intellectual disabilities and developmental delays, affecting both males and females. OPTION C: Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder caused by the absence or malfunction of a specific enzyme called hexosaminidase A. This leads to the accumulation of a fatty substance in the brain and nervous system, causing progressive neurological deterioration.

Extraedge:

Common features seen in both which develop as age progresses: Hepatosplenomegaly Obstructive sleep apnea with a large tongue Prominent forehead with macrocephaly Coarse facial features Valvular heart disease, including regurgitation. Calcifications may also be seen Limited language skills Leucocyte inclusions Mucopolysaccharidosis Short stature Dysostosis multiplex Thick ribs and ovoid vertebral bodies (earliest signs) Since this is a male child aged 5 years and has no feature suggestive of corneal clouding or severe mental disability, diagnosis is more likely Hunter syndrome.

Highyeild:

The Silverman Anderson Score is a clinical assessment tool used to evaluate the severity of respiratory distress in newborns and young infants. It is based on observing specific respiratory signs and chest movements. The score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating more severe respiratory distress.

Table:

#MANTRA Each of the following signs is assigned a score: Retractions (chest wall movements during breathing) Xiphoid (movement of the xiphoid process during breathing) Intercostal (movement between the ribs during breathing) Subcostal (movement below the ribs during breathing) Supraclavicular (movement above the clavicles during breathing) Expulsion of the chest wall Grunting sounds Nasal flaring The total score is the sum of the scores for each of these signs, and a higher score suggests more severe respiratory distress.

questions.text: Maximum steroid produced by fetal adrenal?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DHEA-S After 12 weeks of gestation, the activity of 3 β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (HSD3B) decreases in fetal adrenal, and Sulfo kinase activity increases. At that time (during the mid-gestation, 12–22 weeks), the major steroid products are DHEA and DHEA sulfate (DHEA-S). During mid-gestation (12–22 weeks), the aromatase activity and Sulfo kinase activity increases. So placenta itself utilizes fetal DHEA and DHEA-S as substrate for estrone and estradiol as precursors.

Highyeild:

The fetal adrenal gland is a critical component of the endocrine system during pregnancy and plays a significant role in producing various hormones. Among the steroids produced by the fetal adrenal gland, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S) is the most abundant. DHEA-S is a precursor hormone, meaning it serves as a building block for the synthesis of other hormones, particularly sex hormones such as estrogen and testosterone. DHEA-S production begins early in fetal development and continues throughout pregnancy, reaching its peak during the third trimester. DHEA-S is mainly synthesized in the zona reticularis of the fetal adrenal cortex.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B. Cortisol: Produced in the fetal adrenal cortex, cortisol aids in promoting fetal organ maturation and cardiovascular development. OPTION C. Corticosterone: Another steroid hormone from the adrenal glands, but less studied than cortisol or DHEA-S in fetal development. OPTION D. Progesterone: Produced by the corpus luteum in the ovaries during pregnancy, and while present in the fetal adrenal gland, it is not the maximum steroid produced during fetal development.

Extraedge:

The hormone levels in the fetal circulation are tightly regulated by a complex interplay of factors involving the placenta, fetal pituitary gland, and other endocrine organs. DHEA-S is essential for the development of the fetus and plays a role in promoting fetal growth and maturation. After birth, the production of DHEA-S significantly decreases, and the adrenal gland's focus shifts to producing other hormones like cortisol and aldosterone.

questions.text: A video of sick intubated neonate having bilateral jerks of both right and upper limbs with some occasional twitching of neck as well. Likely seizures:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multifocal clonic Morphology of neonatal seizures Subtle seizures : They are called subtle because the clinical manifestations are mild and are often missed. They are the commonest type, constituting about 50% of all seizures. Common examples of subtle seizures include: Ocular : Tonic horizontal deviation of eyes or sustained eye opening with ocular fixation or cycled fluttering Oral-facial-lingual movements : Chewing, tongue-thrusting, lip-smacking, etc. Limb movements : Cycling, paddling, boxing-jabs, etc. Autonomic phenomena : Tachycardia or bradycardia Apnea Focal clonic seizures : They are rhythmic jerks of one arm, or one leg, or one arm and one leg on the same side of the body. They have both fast and slow components, occur with a frequency of 1–3 jerks per second, and are commonly associated with EEG changes. Multifocal clonic seizures : Characterized by jerks in limbs on both sides of the body. May even involve neck or facial muscles in some cases. May show migration from one side to another or simultaneously occur at multiple sites. Often associated with significant asphyxia and may be seen in sick babies. Topic seizures : This type refers to a sustained flexion or extension of axial or appendicular muscle groups. Not associated with EEG abnormalities and are rare. Tonic-clonic seizures are rare to absent in neonates.

Highyeild:

Multifocal clonic seizures involve repetitive and rhythmic jerking movements affecting different body parts, which could include both upper limbs, as well as occasional twitching in the neck region. These seizures are characterized by abnormal electrical activity in multiple areas of the brain, leading to the simultaneous involvement of different body regions in the jerking movements.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A. Focal clonic: Involves rhythmic jerking movements affecting only one specific area or body part, not multiple regions. OPTION C. Multifocal tonic clonic: Involves both tonic (muscle stiffening) and clonic (rhythmic jerking) movements, affecting multiple body parts. OPTION D. Focal tonic: Involves sustained muscle stiffening in one specific area or body part, not multiple regions.

Highyeild:

The BCG ( Bacillus Calmette-Guérin ) vaccine is primarily known for providing protection against severe forms of tuberculosis (TB) in children, but its effectiveness can vary depending on factors such as age, geographical location, and strain of the TB bacteria. The BCG vaccine has been found to offer protection against both pulmonary and central nervous system (CNS) forms of TB.

Extraedge:

The BCG vaccine was first developed in 1921 by French scientists Albert Calmette and Camille Guerin. It remains one of the most widely used vaccines globally. BCG vaccination is a part of the World Health Organization's (WHO) recommended tuberculosis control program in countries with high TB burden. BCG vaccine has shown some promising off-label effects, including its potential to enhance immune responses against certain non-tuberculosis infections and even some malignancies.

Esophageal temperature probe This is a rectal temperature probe used in neonates in NICU It can also be used to measure the esophageal temperature

Highyeild:

Purpose : An esophageal temperature probe is a medical device used to measure the core body temperature of patients. Insertion : The probe is inserted into the esophagus through the mouth or nose and positioned in the lower third of the esophagus. Temperature Monitoring: Once in place, the probe continuously monitors the patient's core body temperature, providing real-time temperature readings. Applications : Esophageal temperature monitoring is commonly used in surgical settings, intensive care units, and during anesthesia to monitor and manage the patient's body temperature during procedures and recovery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A. Swan-Ganz Catheter: Used to monitor hemodynamic parameters in critically ill patients. Inserted into a central vein and advanced to the pulmonary artery. Monitors central venous pressure, pulmonary artery pressure, and cardiac output. Commonly used in ICU and major surgeries. OPTION B. NAVA Catheter (Neurally Adjusted Ventilatory Assist): Specialized endotracheal tube for mechanical ventilation. Detects diaphragmatic EMG to trigger ventilator breaths. More patient-adaptive, reducing asynchrony and improving comfort. Requires specific ventilators capable of interpreting EMG signals.

Extraedge:

Advantages : Esophageal temperature monitoring offers a more accurate reflection of core body temperature compared to skin temperature measurements, especially in patients undergoing major surgeries or experiencing temperature changes. Risks : Proper placement of the probe is crucial to ensure accurate temperature readings and minimize the risk of complications such as esophageal perforation or discomfort for the patient.
